"llhb","042","11046000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3060","18721209","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Mines and Mining, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Price, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To establish a national school of mines in the North Georgia Agricultural College, at Dahlonega, Georgia; to provide for the selection of a faculty; and to appropriate a sum of money for the support and maintenance thereof. Whereas the North Georgia Agricultural College, formerly the United States branch-mint, located in a region abounding in rich and valuable mines of gold, copper, iron, and other ores, will go into operation in January, eighteen hundred and seventy-three, and will be controlled and managed as required by act of Congress approved April twentieth, eighteen hundred and seventy-one, and also under the provisions of the act of Congress approved July second, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, which provides for colleges for the benefit of agriculture and the mechanic arts, and the liberal and practical education of the industrial classes in the several pursuits and professions in life; and Whereas it is the duty of the Government, while providing schemes for the promotion and development of the interests of agriculture and the mechanic arts, to provide, at the same time, the means for the ready development of the immense hidden wealth of the United States, which can be done in no other way so well as by imparting to the youths of the country a knowledge of those sciences which tend directly to the proper development of our immense mineral resources, which hitherto have received but meager aid from the Government: Therefore,","Committee on Mines and Mining"

Mr. Sypher, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To provide for the construction of a ship-canal near Fort Saint Philip, in the State of Louisiana. "llhb","042","11121000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3090","18721209","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Herndon, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill For the relief of the Alabama, Coostatta, and Muscogee tribes of Indians in Texas. Whereas there are now, and have been for nearly one hundred years, three tribes of Indians, the Alabamas, Coostattas, and Muscogees, numbering in all, at present, about five hundred and twenty-two, residing in Polk County, Texas, and Louisiana; and Whereas said Indians are and have ever been peaceable, quiet, and well disposed toward the whites, and are desirous to still remain in the same section of the State and follow agricultural pursuits; and Whereas said tribes have no lands of their own except a donation of one thousand two hundred and eighty acres of poor land made by the State of Texas, which is wholly inadequate to sustain them, in consequence of which a part of said tribes are now residing in Louisiana, but are anxious to return to Texas and reside with their kindred: Therefore,","Committee on Indian Affairs"

"llhb","042","11270002.tif","042","003","h","2","H.R. 3151","18721216","",""
"llhb","042","11271000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3152","18721216","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Banking and Currency, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Cox, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill For the resumption of specie payments. Whereas, under pressure of "military necessity," certain Treasury notes issued by the United States were declared to be "lawful money," and a "legal tender" in payment of certain debts and demands; and Whereas such "necessity" has long since ceased; and Whereas divers creditors have availed themselves of such notes to discharge their lawful debts in a depreciated currency; and Whereas the substitution of such notes for lawful money has unavoidably tended to inflate prices, beget speculation, foster extravagance, curich the few, impoverish the many, discourage labors, derange trade, intimidate enterprise, and damage public credit at home and abroad, thereby producing innumerable evils in the management of private business and public affairs; and Whereas the faith of the United States was solemnly pledged, on the eighteen day of March, eighteen hundred and sixty-nine, to pay said notes "in coin, or its equivalent," and "to make provision for the redemption thereof in coin at the earliest practicable period;" and Whereas the United States are able to pay all its just debts at maturity; Now, therefore, to prevent a perpetuity of mischief, to keep faith with creditors, and to promote the prosperity of the American people,","Committee on Banking and Currency"

Mr. Duke, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill Repealing all acts imposing taxes upon tobacco. Whereas the tax imposed upon tobacco is most unjust and oppressive to the people of those portions of the United States in which tobacco is grown as a staple crop, in that it is a direct tax upon industry; and Whereas tobacco is largely consumed by the working-classes, who in consequence of this tax, are compelled to pay much more than their just proportion of the taxes: Therefore,","Committee of Ways and Means"

"llhb","042","11305002.tif","042","003","h","2","H.R. 3172","18721216","",""
"llhb","042","11306000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3173","18721216","Read twice, referred to the Committee of Ways and Means, and ordered to be printed. Mr. McIntyre, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To refund certain taxes collected by the United States on raw cotton during the years eighteen hundred and sixty-three, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven, and eighteen hundred and sixty-eight. Whereas the sum of sixty-eight million and seventy-two thousand three hundred and eighty-eight dollars and seventy-nine cents has been collected by the United States as a tax on raw cotton during the years eighteen hundred and sixty-three, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven, and eighteen hundred and sixty-eight, under the provisions of the internal-revenue laws of the United States; and Whereas the judges of the Supreme Court of the United States were equally divided in opinion as to the constitutionality of the laws under which said taxes were collected; and Whereas the burden of said tax has fallen mainly upon the producer, both the white and colored race engaged in producing said cotton, who, while paying this tax on cotton, have, as other citizens of the several States of the United States, paid their due proportion of all other taxes, producing thereby great inequality in the taxes of the country; and Whereas no other raw agricultural product of any of the States has been taxed, even during war; and Whereas it appears on the records of the Internal Revenue Office that there was collected and returned from the State of Alabama ten million three hundred and eight-eight thousand and seventy-two dollars and ten cents; from the State of Arkansas, two million five hundred and fifty-five thousand six hundred and thirty-eight dollars and forty-three cents; from the State of Connecticut one hundred and ninety-three dollars and sixty-four cents; from the State of Florida, nine hundred and eighteen thousand nine hundred and forty-four dollars and ninety-eight cents; from the State of Georgia, eleven million eight hundred and ninety-seven thousand and ninety-four dollars and ninety-eight cents; from the State of Illinois, three hundred and seventy-nine thousand one hundred and forty-four dollars and forty-two cents; from the State of Indiana, ninety-two thousand seven hundred and twenty-seven dollars and twenty-two cents; from the State of Iowa' twenty-seven cents; from the State of Kansas, two hundred and eighty-six dollars and fifteen cents; from the State of Kentucky, five hundred and fifty-three thousand one hundred and twenty-seven dollars and forty-five cents; from the State of Louisiana, ten million and ninety-eight thousand five hundred and one dollar; from the State of Maryland, fifty-one thousand three hundred and forty-nine dollars and fifty-two cents; from the State of Massachusetts, sixty-six-thousand six hundred and seventy-nine dollars and thirty cents; from the State of Mississippi, eight million seven hundred and forty-two thousand nine hundred and ninety-five dollars and ninety-three cents; from the State of Missouri, five hundred and ninety-two thousand and ninety-eight dollars and thirty-six cents; from the State of New Jersey, three thousand six hundred and fifty-six dollars and forty-two cents; from the State of New York eight hundred and sixty-seven thousand nine hundred and forty-two dollars and sixty-eight cents; from the State of North Carolina, one million nine hundred and fifty-nine thousand two hundred and four dollars and eighty-seven cents; from the State of Ohio, four hundred and forty-seven thousand one hundred and twenty-seven dollars and twelve cents; from the State of Pennsylvania, seventy-eight thousand five hundred and thirty-five dollars and six cents; from the State of Rhode Island, two thousand four hundred and twenty-four dollars and thirty-three cents; from the State of South Carolina, four million one hundred and seventy-two thousand four hundred and twenty dollars and sixteen cents; from the State of Tennessee, seven million eight hundred and seventy-three thousand four hundred and sixty dollars and seventy-one cents; from the State of Texas, five million five hundred and two thousand four hundred and one dollars and twenty-four cents; from Utah, one thousand three hundred and seventy-five dollars and thirty-four cents; and from the State of Virginia, eight hundred and twenty-five thousand eight hundred and fifty-six dollars and eighty-seven cents; and Whereas the several States can more conveniently and satisfactorily refund said tax than the Government of the United States; Therefore,","Committee of Ways and Means"

"llhb","042","11312000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3173","18721216","Read twice, referred to the Committee of Ways and Means, and ordered to be printed. Mr. McIntyre, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To refund certain taxes collected by the United States on raw cotton during the years eighteen hundred and sixty-three, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven, and eighteen hundred and sixty-eight. Whereas the sum of sixty-eight million and seventy-two thousand three hundred and eighty-eight dollars and seventy nine cents has been collected by the United States as a tax on raw cotton during the years eighteen hundred and sixty-three, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven, and eighteen hundred and sixty-eight, under the provisions of the internal-revenue laws of the United States; and Whereas the judges of the Supreme Court of the United States were equally divided in opinion as to the constitutionality of the laws under which said taxes were collected; and Whereas the burden of said tax has fallen mainly upon the producer, both the white and colored race engaged in producing said cotton, who, while paying this tax on cotton, have, as other citizens of the several States of the United States, paid their due proportion of all other taxes; producing thereby great inequality in the taxes of the country; and Whereas on other raw agricultural product of any of the States has been taxed, even during the war; and Whereas it appears on the records of the Internal Revenue Office that there was collected and returned from the State of Alabama, ten million three hundred and eighty-eight thousand and seventy-two dollars and ten cents; from the State of Arkansas, two million five hundred and fifty-five thousand six hundred and thirty-eight dollars and forty-three cents; from the State of Connecticut, one hundred and ninety-three dollars and sixty-four cents; from the State of Florida, nine hundred and eighteen thousand nine hundred and forty-four dollars and ninety-eight cents; from the State of Georgia, eleven million eight hundred and ninety-seven thousand and ninety-four dollars and ninety-eight cents; from the State of Illinois, three hundred and seventy-nine thousand one hundred and forty-four dollars and forty-two cents; from the State of Indiana, ninety-two thousand seven hundred and twenty-seven dollars and twenty-two cents; from the State of Iowa, twenty-seven cent;s from the State of Kansas, two hundred and eight-six dollars and fifteen cents; from the State of Kentucky, five hundred and fifty-three thousand one hundred and twenty-seven dollars and forty-five cents; from the State of Louisiana, ten million and ninety-eight thousand five hundred and one dollars; from the State of Maryland fifty-one thousand three hundred and forty-nine dollars and fifty-two cents; from the State of Massachusetts, sixty-six thousand six hundred and seventy-nine dollars and thirty cents; from the State of Mississippi, eight million seven hundred and forty-two thousand nine hundred and ninety-five dollars and ninety-three cents; from the State of Missouri, five hundred and ninety-two thousand and ninety-eight dollars and thirty-six cents; from the State of New Jersey, three thousand six hundred and fifty-six dollars and forty-two cents; from the State of New York, eight hundred and sixty-seven thousand nine hundred and forty-two dollars and sixty-eight cents; from the State of North Carolina, one million nine hundred and fifty-nine thousand two hundred and four dollars and eighty-seven cents; from the State of Ohio, four hundred and forty-seven thousand one hundred and twenty-seven dollars and twelve cents; from the State of Pennsylvania, seventy-eight thousand five hundred and thirty-five dollars and six cents; from the State of Rhode Island, two thousand four hundred and twenty-four dollars and thirty-three cents; from the State of South Carolina, four million one hundred and seventy-two thousand four hundred and twenty dollars and sixteen cents; from the State of Tennessee, seven million eight hundred and seventy-three thousand four hundred and sixty dollars and seventy-one cents; from the State of Texas, five million five hundred and two thousand four hundred and one dollars and twenty-four cents; from Utah, one thousand three hundred and seventy-five dollars and thirty-four cents; and from the State of Virginia, eight hundred and twenty-five thousand eight hundred and fifty-six dollars and eighty-seven cents; and Whereas the several States can more conveniently and satisfactorily refund said tax than the Government of the United States: Therefore,","Committee of Ways and Means"

"llhb","042","11328000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3179","18721216","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Commerce, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Stevenson, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To accept the Louisville and Portland Canal, and to reduce the tolls thereof. Whereas the stock of the Louisville and Portland Canal Company is owned and held by the United States, expecting five shares held by the directors of said company; and Whereas said canal has been enlarged chiefly by the United States; and Whereas it is practically part of the Ohio River and necessary to the navigation of that stream; and Whereas the tolls now charged and collected by said company are excessive and burdensome to commerce; and Whereas the State of Kentucky has, by her legislature, adopted the following resolution for the transfer of said canal, and the property of said company connected therewith, to the United States, to wit: "Resolution in relation to the Louisville and Portland Canal. "Whereas All the stock in the Louisville and Portland Canal belongs to the United States Government, except five shares owned by the directors of the Louisville and Portland Canal Company; and said directors, under the authority of the legislation of Kentucky and the United States, executed a mortgage to secure bonds named in said mortgage, some of which are out and unpaid; and said canal company may owe other debts; and "Whereas it is right and proper that the Government of the United States should assume the control and management of said canal: Therefore, "Be it resolved by the general assembly of the commonwealth of Kentucky, That the president and directors of the Louisville and Portland Canal Company are hereby authorized and directed to surrender the said canal, all the property connected therewith, to the Government of the United States upon the following terms and conditions: "First, that the Government of the United States shall not levy tolls upon said canal, except so much as may be necessary to keep the same in repair, pay all necessary superintendence, custody, and expense, and make all necessary improvements. "Secondly, that the city of Louisville shall have the right to throw bridges over the canal at such points as said city may deem proper: Provided always, That said bridges shall be so located as not to interfere with the use of the canal, and so constructed as not to interfere with its navigation. "Thirdly, that the title and possession of the United States of said canal shall not interfere with the right of the State to serve criminal and civil processes, and with the State's general police powers over the territory covered by the said canal and appendages. "Fourthly, and further, that the city of Louisville shall at all, times have the right of drainage into said canal: Provided, That the connections between the drains and canal shall be made upon the most approved plan to keep out mud and garbage. "Fifthly, that the use of the water-power of said canal shall be guaranteed forever to the actual owners of property contiguous to said canal, its branches and dams, subject to such restrictions and regulations as may be made by the Secretary of that Department of the United States Government which may have charge of the said canal. "Sixthly, that the Government of the United States shall, before such surrender, discharge said mortgage, and pay all debts due by the said canal company, and purchase the stock of said directors.","Committee on Commerce"

"llhb","042","11351000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3195","18721616","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Packard, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To authorize the President of the United States to request the republic of Hayti to indemnify Antonio Pelletier. Whereas Antonio Pelletier, a citizen of the United States, naturalized in the year eighteen hundred and fifty-two, did, during the month of August or September, eighteen hundred and sixty, purchase of a United States marshal, at public auction, at the port of Key West, the bark William; and the subsequently the said Pelletier shipped a crew and placed a cargo of merchandise on board the said vessel and proceeded on a trading voyage to the West Indies; and that while in pursuance of his said legitimate commercial enterprise his said vessel, under stress of weather, was cast upon a reef, designated as Caico, off the coast of Hayti, in the mouth of February, eighteen hundred and sixty-one, and after drifting for several days the bark came to anchor in the port of Fort Liberte, Hayti; and that after making some slight repairs, and being informed that the port of Fort Liberte was not open to commerce, anchor was weighed and the bark proceeded down the bay until near the fort, when the prevailing breeze failed, and the vessel drifted on the reef opposite the fort, where the tide left her high and dry, when certain authorities of the republic of Hayti boarded the said bark William, arrested the said Antonio Pelletier and his crew, and carried them ashore and consigned them to prison, without cause or proper trial, holding the said Pelletier, the master and owner of the vessel aforesaid, a close prisoner for the period of nearly three years, condemning him to death, and subjecting him to the most cruel treatment, from which he finally escaped by the assistance of the agents of foreign governments; and that during his imprisonment his said vessel and cargo were seized and confiscated by the authorities of the republic of Hayti; and that his said imprisonment, spoliation, and consequent losses amounted to the financial damages of the said Pelletier in the sum of six hundred and thirteen thousand eight hundred dollars; and further, that the imprisonment and inhuman treatment to which the said Pelletier was subjected resulted in the serious impairing of his health, and rendered him an invalid and crippled for life, for which afflictions it is almost impossible to estimate in moneyed damages; and Whereas the facts above recited are evidenced by executive document numbered two hundred and sixty, second session of the Fortieth Congress, furnished by the Secretary of State in response to House resolution of the tenth March, anno Domini eighteen hundred and sixty-eight: Now, therefore,","Committee on Foreign Affairs"

"llhb","042","11389000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3219","18721216","Read twice, referred to the Committee on the Public Lands, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Palmer, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill For the relief of Robert Coles, of Chariton, Lucas County, Iowa. Whereas it appearing that, in accordance with the laws of the State of Iowa, the board of supervisors of Lucas County, in said State, on the second day of November, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, entered into a contract with Robert Coles, conveying to him "all the right, title, and interest which may accrue to Lucas County under the laws of the State of Iowa, to the swamp-lands situated in said county, or indemnification for lands sold for cash, or located with land-warrants, after the passage of the act of September twenty-eight, eighteen hundred and fifty," under "the act of March second, eighteen hundred and fifty-five;" and it further appearing that the necessary proof to secure said indemnification was on file in the General Land-Office as early as the month of June, eighteen hundred and sixty, and action was not had thereon, owing to the failure of the surveyor-general to certify up the list of swamp selections made by the proper agent, as required by the Secretary of the Interior, until after the passage of "the act of March fifth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, for the relief of Lucas and other counties in the State of Iowa," when, on the twenty-eight day of March, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, "swamp-indemnity scrip, number ninety-two," for two thousand three hundred and sixty-three acres and twenty-six hundredths of an acre was issued to the State of Iowa under the "act of March second, eighteen hundred and fifty-five," and on the fifteenth day of April, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, "swamp-indemnity scrip, number ninety-three," was also issued for thirty-six and thirty-six hundredths of an acre, all for swamp-lands in Lucas County, State of Iowa, and located with land-warrants after the passage of the "act of September twenty-eight, eighteen hundred and fifty;" and it further appearing that according to the laws of the State of Iowa the said Robert Coles is duly authorized to locate said scrip on behalf of the same; and it further appearing that at the time said contract was entered into between the board of supervisors and Robert Coles, as above stated, there were large quantities of unsold public land in the State of Iowa; and it appearing that at this time, and ever since said scrip was issued, there are no public lands in said State of Iowa upon, which the same can be located: Therefore,","Committee on the Public Lands"

"llhb","042","11530000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3260","18721219","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, and ordered to be printed. Mr. McKinney, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill For the relief of David W. Stockstill, of Sidney, Ohio. Whereas on the twenty-seventh day of September, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, one Henry S. Stockstill, of Selby County, Ohio, was drafted into the service of the United States; and Whereas on the nineteenth day of December, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, one David W. Stockstill, a brother of said Henry S. Stockstill, of the same county and State, procured a substitute, named Frank Schooley, to serve in place of said Henry S. Stockstill, to whom he paid the sum of seven hundred dollars; and Whereas the said substitute, frank Schooley, was mustered into the service of the United States, and honorably served the Government until discharged; and Whereas the said Henry S. Stockstill was not discharged by reason of having furnished said substitute, but was required to serve out his time for which he was drafted: Therefore,","Committee on Military Affairs"

"llhb","042","11678000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3307","18730106","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Commerce, and ordered to be printed. Mr. John B. Hawley, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To provide for the appointment of commissioners to collect information in relation to railroads forming lines of commerce between States, and for other purposes. Whereas by the Constitution of the United States, power is vested in Congress to regulate commerce among the several States; and Whereas the unreasonable and extortionate charges of the various railroad companies whose roads form lines of commerce extending from State to State have, in many parts of the country, become burdensome and oppressive to the people; and the reckless and careless manner in which such roads are managed and operated greatly endangering the lives of passengers transported thereon: Therefore, for the purpose of enabling Congress to correct these abuses and regulate the rates of transportation of passengers and freight, and secure greater safety and regularity in such transportation on the various lines of railroads extending from State to State,","Committee on Commerce"

"llhb","042","12055000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3430","18730113","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Shanks, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To repeal an act entitled "An act for the relief of certain Indians in the Central superintendency," approved June tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, and to settle by commission all rights and equities respecting the property to which said act refers. Whereas by an act entitled "An act for the relief of certain Indians in the Central superintendency," approved June tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, the Secretary of the Interior was authorized and directed to appoint three commissioners, and to take an inventory of, appraise, and sell certain lands, bonds, notes, accounts, contracts, mortgages, and other property or assets held or acquired in any manner under a trust in respect to education, created and confirmed by treaties with the Ottawa Indians of Blanchard's Fork and Roche de Boeuf, proclaimed July twenty-eighth, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, and October fourteenth, eighteen hundred and sixty-eight, and to pay the proceeds of such sale to the several members of the said tribe, their heirs or assigns, per capita; and Whereas counter-claims of rights and equities in said lands, bonds, notes, accounts, contracts, mortgages, and other property or assets having been set forth and affirmed by the trustees under said trust, and by the American Baptist Home Mission Society, the Secretary of the Interior, having appointed said commissioners, and having obtained through them the said inventory and appraisal, has referred to Congress the question of further legislation; and Whereas representatives of all the said parties have united in an agreement to make friendly application to Congress for legislation providing for the ascertainment, severance, and satisfaction, by commission, of the equitable interests of the contending parties: Now, therefore, in order that the most perfect justice may be done in the premises to all the said parties,","Committee on Indian Affairs"

"llhb","042","12631000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3593","18730120","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Private Land-Claims, and ordered to be printed. Mr. McGrew, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To confirm to William Marvin the title to seven thousand acres of land in the State of Florida. Whereas under the act of Congress approved June twenty-second, eighteen hundred and sixty, entitled, "An act for the final adjustment of private land-claims in the States of Florida, Louisiana, and Missouri, and for other purposes," and extended by an act of Congress, approved March second, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven, entitled "An act to extend the provisions of an act entitled 'An act for the final adjustment of private land-claims in the States of Florida, Louisiana, and Missouri, and for other purposes,'" the register and the receiver at the land-office at Tallahassee, Florida, acting as commissioners under the acts aforesaid, have reported to the Commissioner of the General Land-Office that there ought to be confirmed to William Marvin, who holds under Bernardo Segui, under class two, under the third section of the act first aforesaid, a tract of land containing seven thousand acres, in the State of Florida, on the east side of the Saint John's River, between the place called Dunn's Lake and that known as Horse Landing, including in said tract of land the place called Buffaloe Bluff, and includes parts of sections twenty-eight, thirty-three, thirty-four, thirty-five, thirty-six, and thirty-nine, in township ten south, of range twenty-six east; and sections and parts of sections one, two, three, eleven twelve, and thirty-nine, in township eleven south, of range twenty-six east; and parts of sections five, six, seven, eight, and forty, in township eleven south, of range twenty-seven east; which claim is based upon a grant or concession by the Spanish government to Bernardo Segui, before the twenty-fourth of January, eighteen hundred and eighteen; and whereas the Commissioner of the General Land-Office has approved the report of the said commissioners, and has reported the same to Congress for its action, and recommended the confirmation of the title to the said seven thousand acres of land to the said William Marvin, as the legal representative of Bernardo Segui: Therefore,","Committee on Private Land-Claims"

"llhb","042","12757000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3669","18730127","Read twice, referred to the Committee of Ways and Means, and ordered to be printed. Mr. James B. Beck, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To refund certain taxes collected by the Government of the United States on raw cotton exported. Whereas by the act of Congress approved July thirteenth, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, and the amended act approved March second, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven, taxes were imposed upon raw or unmanufactured cotton, with the provision that "no drawback shall in any case be allowed on raw or unmanufactured cotton of any tax paid thereon when exported in the raw unmanufactured condition;" and Whereas it appears that two-thirds of the cotton produced in the years eighteen hundred and sixty-six and eighteen hundred and sixty-seven was, in fact, exported, and that the tax of three cents per pound on the crop of eighteen hundred and sixty-six, and of two and one-half cents per pound on the crop of eighteen hundred and sixty-seven, collected thereon by the Government of the United States, under the laws aforesaid, is still withheld from the producers of said cotton so exported, by whom the burden of said tax was borne, although sometimes paid to the United States officers by and receipted for to others, which is believed to be in conflict with that provision of the Constitution of the United States which declares that "no tax or duty shall be laid on articles exported from any State:" Therefore,","Committee of Ways and Means"

"llhb","042","12844000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3704","18730127","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Commerce, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Ritchie, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To provide for the examination or survey of a route to connect the Ohio River and the seaboard by canal or slackwater navigation by the way of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. Whereas the President in his last annual message recommended as part of a system of internal improvements to be favorably considered by Congress the establishment of canal or slackwater navigation between the Ohio River and tidewater, by an extension of the Kanawha and James River Canal and for the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal; and Whereas the United States are stockholders in the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company to the extent of two million five hundred thousand dollars, and it is alleged that the shortest, most eligible, and least expensive route for such navigation is by way of the said canal; and Whereas before Congress adopts the policy of undertaking such a system of improvements, or decides to aid any proposed route for the establishment of the water communication described, it should have full and reliable information: Therefore,","Committee on Commerce"

"llhb","042","12848000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3707","18730127","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Adams, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill For the benefit of sundry citizens of Eastern Kentucky who volunteered to aid in the protection of supplies for the Army. Whereas in the fall of eighteen hundred and sixty-two, in obedience to the call of Captain John B. Auxier, Thirty-ninth Regiment Kentucky Infantry, then commanding United States forces sent to guard supplies being transported in boats up the Big Sandy River for the use of the Army, a number of citizens in Eastern Kentucky volunteered to assist said forces in protecting said supplies against an anticipated attack from the enemy; and Whereas said citizens, after being furnished with guns and ammunition by said commanding officer, did, on or about the fourth day of December, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, participate in an engagement with the enemy for the protection of said supplies, which resulted in the defeat of said United States forces, and in which many of said citizens were captured by the enemy, and for several months held in close confinement as prisoners of war: Now, therefore,","Committee on Military Affairs"
"llhb","042","12849002.tif","042","003","h","2","H.R. 3707","18730127","",""
"llhb","042","12850000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3708","18730127","Read twice, referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Cox, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To repeal an act entitled "An act for the relief of certain Indians in the Central superintendency," approved June tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two. Whereas the act of Congress approved June tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, entitled "An act for the relief of certain Indians in the Central superintendency," directed the seizure and sale by the United States of the entire property of the Ottawa University, in Franklin County, Kansas, without making compensation to said corporation, and without any judicial condemnation of said property; and Whereas said act cannot be carried into effect, because the trustees of said university are in legal possession of said property and refuse to surrender the same, and claim that said act of Congress is unconstitutional and void: Therefore,","Committee on the Judiciary"

"llhb","042","13209000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3886","18730210","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Duell, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill For the relief of William Blanchard, late consul of the United States at Melbourne, Australia. Whereas the Government of the United States obtained an award before the board of arbitration at Geneva, of several millions of dollars, for the destruction of our shipping by the Sea King, (Shenandoah;) and Whereas, in consequence of the efforts and correspondence of said consul in the voluntary capacity of charge d'affaires, he convicted the colonial government at Melbourne of negligence of duty, violation of treaty obligations, and of Her Majesty's neutrality proclamation; and Whereas this conviction of the colonial government at Melbourne, through the said correspondence, together with the evidence furnished the United States, procured by great vigilance and energy on his part, and under circumstances of peculiar difficulty, enabled the Government to recover the large award aforesaid; and Whereas the said consul also expended a large amount of his private funds in an attempt to capture and blow up, with a torpedo, said Shenandoah, in the port of Melbourne: Therefore,","Committee on Foreign Affairs"

"llhb","042","13216000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3891","18730210","Read twice, referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Killinger, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill For the relief of James W. Bowen, late provost-marshal of the tenth congressional district of Pennsylvania. Whereas Andrew B. Neugardt, a son of Jacob Neugardt, of Upper Mahantango Township, Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, and within the tenth congressional district of said State, was drafted in the fall of the year eighteen hundred and sixty-four, to serve for the period of three years in the Army of the United States; and Whereas the said Jacob Neugardt procured Simon B. Neugardt, another of his sons, to be accepted and mustered into the service as the substitute for the said Andrew B. Neugardt; and Whereas the said Jacob Neugardt afterward induced his said son to desert from the Army, whereupon James W. Bowen, then the provost-marshal of said tenth congressional district, in pursuance of orders from the War Department, caused the said Jacob Neugardt to be arrested and detained for inducing his son to desert, and discharged him upon voluntarily depositing the sum of six hundred and twenty-five dollars to procure another substitute, and which substitute was procured and mustered into the service of the United States, and a certificate of discharge of said Simon B. Neugardt issued and delivered to the said Jacob Neugardt; and Whereas the said Jacob Neugardt afterward repudiated the transaction, denied the deposit of the money for the purpose aforesaid, and brought suit and recovered judgment against the said James W. Bowen in the courts of Pennsylvania, and he, the said James W. Bowen, was compelled to refund the sum out of his own private means: Therefore,","Committee on the Judiciary"

Mr. Ritchie, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To appropriate three hundred thousand dollars for the relief of Frederick City, and the banks thereof, for losses occasioned by the confederate army July ninth, eighteen hundred and sixty-four. Whereas on the ninth day of July, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, during the invasion by the confederate army, under command of General Jubal E. Early, a demand was made by order of that officer upon the corporate authorities of the city of Frederick, as a city within hostile territory, for the sum of two hundred thousand dollars, for the use of said army, under penalty of forcible and indiscriminate seizure and appropriation, throughout said city, of such supplies as might be needed; and Whereas the said corporate authorities, in order to meet said exaction or ransom, and thereby save said city from the spoliation menaced, did forthwith borrow said amount from the banking institutions of said city, in proportion to their capital stock, and pay over the same to the officers appointed to receive the same, as required: Therefore,","Committee of Claims"

Mr. Barry, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To aid the American Printing-House and University for the Blind. Whereas the great expense of providing facilities for the education of the blind precludes the investment of private capital; and Whereas there have not heretofore been published a series of textbooks and sufficient literature in raised print, or illustrative apparatus addressed to the touch, nor means of instruction in the higher branches of a liberal education; and Whereas a responsible organization has been incorporated in the District of Columbia, whose object is to furnish the aforesaid facilities to the blind of the whole country; and Whereas considerable funds have been pledged and donated in the furtherance of the said organization; and Whereas the sum of one hundred thousand dollars will enable the board of regents of the said national institution to place it on a permanent basis: Now, therefore,","Committee for the District of Columbia"

"llhb","042","13626000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3923","18730213","Read twice and referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs. An Act To authorize the President of the United States to negotiate with the Creek Indians for a cession of a portion of their reservation. Whereas by the third article of the treaty concluded with the Creek Indians, June fourteenth, one thousand eight hundred and sixty-six, said Indians ceded to the United States, for the settlement of friendly Indians and freedmen, the west half of their entire domain, to be divided by a line running north and south; and Whereas the recent survey of said line, made in conformity with the provisions of said treaty, includes within the limits of the Creek reservation, east of said line, some of the improvements made on a reservation selected on what was supposed to be Creek ceded lands for the Seminole tribe of Indians, which reservation is provided for in their treaty of March first, one thousand eight hundred and sixty-six, and also some of the improvements of the Sac and Fox of the Mississippi tribe of Indians, made on a reservation intended to be established in accordance with the provisions of their treaty of February eighth, one thousand eight hundred and sixty-seven; and Whereas said improvements have been made upon said lands by and for the aforesaid Indians, who have settled thereupon in good faith, in accordance with treaty stipulations; and Whereas it is necessary, in order to secure these improvements to said Indians, and to ensure them suitable reservations, that the lands occupied thereby should be granted to them. Therefore,","Committee on Indian Affairs"

"llhb","042","13738000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3974","18730217","Read twice, referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and ordered to be printed. Mr. James B. Beck, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill To regulate the appearance and compensation of agents and attorneys prosecuting or demands before Congress or the Executive Departments of the Government, and for other purposes. Whereas the secret employment of persons by those interested in legislation before Congress, and in the payment of claims by the Departments of the Government for the purpose of influencing members of Congress and Government officials in legislation and official conduct, has grown to be note only a system utterly corrupt and demoralizing against public policy, subversive of justice, and a fraud alike upon the employer and the Treasury, but also unjust and derogatory to the character, for honesty and integrity, of those in position and office who desire to act alone for the public good: Therefore,","Committee on the Judiciary"

"llhb","042","13760000.tif","042","003","h","","H.R. 3984","18730217","Read twice, referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs, and ordered to be printed. Mr. Averill, on leave, introduced the following bill: A Bill Confirming articles of agreement with Shoshone and Bannock tribe of Indians, and directing the Secretary of the Interior to carry the same into effect. Whereas by act of Congress approved June firth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, entitled "An act to authorize the President of the United States to negotiate with the chiefs and head-men of the Shoshone and Bannock tribe of Indians for the relinquishment of a portion of their reservation in Wyoming Territory," power is given the President to make such negotiation; and Whereas said act makes it the duty of the President to report his proceedings thereunder to Congress for approval or rejections; and Whereas the President did, through his duly-authorized commissioner, negotiate and make with said Indians the following agreement, to wit: Whereas it appears by the records of the above negotiation, now on file in the office of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, that the provisions of said act of Congress directing the exchange of lands, acre for acre, with said Indians, was not desired by them, but the above and foregoing agreement for the cession to the United States of a portion of their reservation, according to the provisions therein contained, being preferred by them, is accepted by the United States: Therefore,","Committee on Indian Affairs"
